stem: Before using a portable angle grinder, which check is mandatory?

choices.text: Remove the guard to access tight spots
Use any wheel that fits the arbor
Verify the guard is fitted and the wheel RPM rating meets or exceeds tool RPM
Lubricate the wheel with oil for a smoother cut

rationales.C: A properly fitted guard and a wheel rated for the tool speed prevent wheel burst.

stem: What should you do if a power tool’s cord insulation is damaged?

choices.text: Wrap it with tape and continue working
Use it only on GFCI-protected outlets
Tag it out and remove it from service until repaired
Flip the plug to restore the ground

rationales.C: Defective tools must be removed from service and tagged until properly repaired.

stem: Why should welding work leads and connections be tight and clean?

choices.text: They reduce voltage drop and overheating at the connections
Smaller cable always saves weight without consequences

rationales.C: Good electrical contact minimizes resistance, heat buildup, and erratic arc behavior.

stem: Which is correct for maintaining an electrode holder?

choices.text: Minor cracks in insulation are acceptable
Jaws should be oily to reduce sticking
Insulation must be intact and jaws clean with no exposed conductors
Cool the holder in water after heavy use

rationales.C: Sound insulation and clean jaws prevent shock and overheating.

stem: What is the recommended setup angle for a straight ladder?

choices.text: 4:1 (about 75°) slope from the base to the support
Lean as steep as possible to save space
Lay it nearly horizontal for stability

rationales.B: The 4:1 rule provides stable footing and proper contact with the support.

stem: How does sling angle affect tension in a two-leg lift?

choices.text: Smaller angles reduce tension in each leg
Smaller angles increase tension in each leg
Angle has no effect on leg tension

rationales.B: As the angle from horizontal decreases, leg tension rises significantly.

stem: Which statement about crane hand signals is correct?

choices.text: Only the operator may signal a stop
Anyone may give the universal emergency stop signal
Two hands above head always means 'speed up'
There are no standard hand signals for cranes

rationales.B: The emergency stop is universal and may be given by any person observing danger.

stem: When the exact weight of a load is unknown, what is the safest approach?

choices.text: Guess the weight by the size of the load
Use rated slings and perform a short, controlled trial lift
Ride on the load to watch clearances

rationales.B: A brief trial lift lets you verify balance and capacity while staying within control.

stem: What eye and face protection is appropriate for grinding?

choices.text: Safety glasses and a face shield together
No eye protection for quick touch‑ups

rationales.C: Use both safety glasses and a face shield to protect against high‑energy debris.

stem: How long should a fire watch typically remain after hot work ends?

choices.text: Not required if the area looks clean
Only while cutting is in progress
A fire extinguisher replaces the fire watch

rationales.B: A post‑work fire watch of ~30 minutes is common practice to catch smoldering ignition.

stem: Which oxygen range is considered acceptable for entry into a confined space?

choices.text: Any level if wearing a respirator

rationales.B: Atmospheres between ~19.5% and 23.5% oxygen are considered acceptable for entry.

stem: After isolating and locking equipment, what should be done before starting work?

choices.text: Remove the locks briefly to test
Attempt a start to verify zero energy
Ask a coworker to avoid touching controls

rationales.B: Verification by attempting a start confirms all energy sources are neutralized.

stem: Why are welding screens used around a work area?

choices.text: They only improve the welder’s visibility
They protect others from arc flash and flying sparks
They reduce fumes below limits by themselves

rationales.B: Screens help shield bystanders from UV radiation and ejected particles.

stem: What is the primary purpose of a Welding Procedure Specification (WPS)?

choices.text: To define essential variables and parameters for production welds
For inspectors only; welders need not read it

rationales.B: The WPS guides the welder with qualified ranges for variables such as current, position, and preheat.

stem: Which practice is correct when using fabrication drawings?

choices.text: Use the latest revision listed in the title block
Let the shop choose per day

rationales.B: Always confirm and work to the current drawing revision to avoid rework.

stem: Why apply 5S/housekeeping in a welding shop?

choices.text: It reduces waste and improves safety
It means sweeping at the end of the day only

rationales.B: Orderly workplaces cut search time, trip hazards, and defects.

stem: Which is a sound sequence for organizing a welding job?

choices.text: Start welding, then look for parts
Confirm materials/tools, review WPS & drawings, plan sequence, then set up

rationales.B: Planning with the current WPS/drawings and confirmed materials prevents delays and rework.

stem: What does a fillet‑weld gauge measure?

choices.text: Fillet leg size or effective throat

rationales.B: Fillet gauges verify leg length and throat to drawing or code requirements.

stem: Why remove oil, rust, paint, and mill scale before welding?

choices.text: To reduce porosity and lack of fusion

rationales.B: Contaminants cause gas generation and prevent fusion at the interface.

stem: How should preheat be verified?

choices.text: With temperature‑indicating crayons or a thermometer

rationales.B: Use objective temperature indicators to confirm required preheat.

stem: How should tack welds be placed to control distortion?

choices.text: All tacks on one side of the joint
Balanced around the joint to hold alignment

rationales.B: Balanced, adequate tacks hold fit‑up and reduce distortion during welding.

stem: What should be done between weld passes with flux‑shielded processes?

choices.text: Water‑quench slag to speed the job

rationales.B: Cleaning between passes prevents slag inclusions and improves fusion.

stem: What should be done at the end of a weld bead?

choices.text: Blend and fill the crater before stopping
Strike a new arc on the finished face

rationales.B: Filling craters reduces the risk of crater cracking.

stem: How should power source polarity be chosen?

choices.text: Use the same polarity for all processes
Follow the WPS and consumable manufacturer requirements

rationales.B: Different processes and wires/rods require specific polarity for proper fusion.

stem: What is the 3‑4‑5 rule used for in layout?

choices.text: Checking 90° squareness by measuring a 3‑4‑5 triangle

rationales.B: A 3‑4‑5 triangle forms a right angle, useful for verifying squareness.

stem: Why account for cutting kerf in layout?

choices.text: It is negligible for all processes
To maintain final dimensions after cutting

rationales.B: Kerf removes material; planning for it preserves required part size.

stem: Why use a center punch during layout?

choices.text: To preserve hole/mark location during cutting or drilling

rationales.B: Punch marks help keep locations visible and guide drill points.

stem: How should a steel rule be read for accuracy?

choices.text: Read to the smallest graduation on the rule

rationales.B: Read the finest graduation available to reduce measurement error.

stem: What is a good practice for choosing a datum in layout?

choices.text: Select a single clear datum to control accumulated error

rationales.B: A single, consistent datum minimizes tolerance stack‑up.

stem: Why include bend allowance when laying out bent parts?

choices.text: Metal does not stretch during bending
To achieve the required finished lengths after bending

rationales.B: Material stretches/compresses in bends; allowing for it preserves sizes.

stem: Which method helps transfer equal measurements accurately?

choices.text: Use dividers or a combination square
Use chalk and estimate by eye
Wave a hand near the part

rationales.A: Dividers and squares allow precise transfer of repeated distances.

stem: How should precision layout tools be stored?

choices.text: Keep scribes dull and toss squares in a bin
Protect edges and faces to preserve accuracy

rationales.B: Protecting edges maintains the accuracy of rules, squares, and gauges.

stem: Why use templates or jigs for repeat parts?

choices.text: They speed production and reduce measurement error

rationales.B: Templates produce consistent parts and reduce layout effort.

stem: How can you keep layout lines visible during cutting/fitting?

choices.text: Use contrasting markers or soapstone and refresh as needed
Use permanent paint on all metals
No indication is needed on stainless

rationales.B: High‑contrast marks remain visible through handling and light grinding.

stem: Why is a consistent root opening important before welding a butt joint?

choices.text: It has no effect on penetration
It helps control penetration and root fusion
A completely closed gap is always best
A very large gap prevents burn‑through

rationales.B: Uniform root gaps help achieve consistent root fusion without burn‑through.

stem: Why choose a proper bevel angle during prep?

choices.text: The right angle allows access and proper penetration

rationales.B: Adequate groove angle lets the electrode/torch reach the root and sidewalls.

stem: What is the purpose of a backing bar or strip?

choices.text: It supports the root pass and helps prevent burn‑through
It is forbidden by all codes

rationales.A: Backing provides support and can aid complete joint penetration.

stem: How can hi‑lo (internal misalignment) be minimized during fit‑up?

choices.text: Use clamps, hi‑lo tools, and alignment fixtures
Hammer it flush after the weld cools
Rely on weld metal to fill the offset

rationales.B: Proper clamping and alignment tools set parts flush before welding.

stem: What is the function of strongbacks during fabrication?

choices.text: They prevent distortion and hold alignment while welding

rationales.B: Strongbacks restrain parts to counteract weld shrinkage.

stem: How should tack welds be sized?

choices.text: Sized so they can be fused into the final weld

rationales.B: Properly sized tacks fuse into the weld without defects.

stem: Why use skip or backstep welding sequences?

choices.text: To concentrate heat in one area
To distribute heat and reduce distortion
To always weld straight through in one pass

rationales.B: Sequencing spreads heat input and limits distortion.

stem: What are bridge tacks used for?

choices.text: They are forbidden for any process

rationales.A: Bridge tacks hold edges where gaps exist until proper welding occurs.

stem: Why install run‑on and run‑off tabs?

choices.text: To achieve full fusion at tie‑ins and protect part edges

rationales.B: Tabs allow starting/ending outside the part for complete fusion.

stem: How do chill bars help when welding thin material?

choices.text: They extract heat to control distortion

rationales.B: Heat sinks pull heat away to limit distortion and burn‑through.

stem: Why use shims during fit‑up?

choices.text: To ensure a consistent root gap when parts vary

rationales.A: Temporary shims help set uniform gaps before welding.

stem: Why mark part orientation before tacking/welding?

choices.text: They are not allowed on steel

rationales.B: Orientation marks help ensure parts are positioned as designed.

stem: Why remove burrs and oxides from prepared edges?

choices.text: It saves time but reduces strength
It is unnecessary on any material
It improves fusion and reduces inclusions

rationales.C: Clean, smooth edges promote full fusion and fewer inclusions.

stem: How should distortion be addressed during fabrication planning?

choices.text: Plan fit and sequence to allow for predicted shrinkage
Clamps cause distortion and should be avoided
Heat input is unrelated to distortion

rationales.B: Anticipating shrinkage lets you set counter‑measures like sequencing and fixturing.

stem: When should fit‑up be verified?

choices.text: Before welding—check dimensions, gaps, and angles
Skip if the schedule is tight

rationales.B: Verifying fit‑up beforehand prevents defects and rework.

stem: What is the safe use rule for cut‑off wheels?

choices.text: Side‑grind with heavy pressure for speed
Do not side‑grind with cut‑off wheels
It is fine with the guard removed

rationales.B: Cut‑off wheels are not designed for side loads and can shatter.

stem: Why are paper blotters used between grinding wheel flanges and the wheel?

choices.text: They distribute clamping force and protect the wheel

rationales.B: Blotters cushion and spread load to reduce stress concentrations.

stem: How should a grinder guard be positioned?

choices.text: Place the guard between the wheel and the operator

rationales.B: The guard should block fragments and direct debris away from the user.

stem: How should bonded abrasive wheels be stored?

choices.text: In a damp area to keep cool
Dry, flat, and protected from dropping

rationales.B: Moisture and impacts damage wheels; keep them dry and supported.

stem: How should wheel RPM ratings relate to tool RPM?

choices.text: Wheel rating may be below tool speed
Wheel rating must meet or exceed the tool’s maximum RPM
Any mismatch is fine for brief use

rationales.B: A wheel must be rated for at least the tool’s maximum rotational speed.

stem: Which description matches a neutral oxy‑fuel flame?

choices.text: A balanced inner cone with no feather
An oxidizing feather on the inner cone
A loud, popping flame with backfire

rationales.B: Neutral flame has a well‑defined cone and no acetylene feather.

stem: Which statement about backfire vs flashback is correct?

choices.text: Backfire means flame travels into the hoses
Flashback is flame burning into the torch/hose; backfire is a momentary pop

rationales.B: Backfire is a brief pop at the tip; flashback sustains into the torch/hose and is hazardous.

stem: What is a good technique for piercing a plate with oxy‑fuel?

choices.text: Place the tip flat and go to full oxygen immediately
Tilt the tip, preheat, then use the oxygen jet to pierce

rationales.B: Preheating and a slight tilt help prevent blowback and tip damage.

stem: Which statement about oxy‑fuel hose/torch threads is true?

choices.text: Fuel gas fittings use right‑hand threads
Fuel gas fittings use left‑hand threads with notches

rationales.B: Fuel gas fittings are left‑hand (often with notches); oxygen is right‑hand to prevent mixups.

stem: What is the correct practice regarding oxygen equipment?

choices.text: Use oil or grease to prevent leaks
Never use oil or grease on oxygen equipment
Do not crack cylinder valves before attaching regulators

rationales.B: Oil/grease can ignite violently in pure oxygen.

stem: What is the purpose of 'cracking' cylinder valves briefly before attaching regulators?

choices.text: To blow dust/debris away from the outlet seat

rationales.B: Cracking clears contaminants that could damage regulators.

stem: What is the maximum recommended working pressure for acetylene?

choices.text: Do not use acetylene above 15 psi (≈103 kPa)
Any pressure is fine with arrestors

rationales.B: Acetylene becomes unstable above ~15 psi; keep working pressure below this limit.

stem: How should torch standoff be managed in plasma arc cutting (PAC)?

choices.text: Always drag the tip regardless of torch design
Maintain the proper standoff/drag per the torch to protect consumables

rationales.B: Correct standoff prevents nozzle damage and preserves cut quality.

stem: Heavy bottom dross is usually a sign of what?

rationales.B: Slow travel lets molten metal solidify on the lower edge, forming heavy dross.

stem: Which polarity is typical for air plasma cutting systems?

rationales.B: Air plasma torches commonly use DCEN: electrode negative, work positive.

stem: Why use dry, clean compressed air for PAC?

choices.text: Wet, oily air extends consumable life
Dry, clean air reduces wear and improves cut quality
Nitrogen is always required instead of air

rationales.B: Moisture and oil contaminate the plasma stream and damage consumables.

stem: What is the advantage of pilot‑arc or HF start in PAC?

choices.text: They require scraping the nozzle on the work
They initiate the arc without dragging the nozzle
They reduce the need for shielding

rationales.B: Non‑contact starts protect the nozzle and improve reliability.

stem: Which polarity is standard for air carbon arc gouging (CAC‑A) with DC?

rationales.B: DCEP helps blow molten metal out of the groove effectively.

stem: What air supply is required for CAC‑A?

choices.text: High‑volume, dry air to blow molten metal clear

rationales.B: A high‑volume stream of dry compressed air clears molten metal from the groove.

stem: What is a typical electrode angle for CAC‑A?

choices.text: Lead the electrode 15–20° in the travel direction

rationales.B: A small lead angle directs the molten metal out of the gouge.

stem: Which PPE is most appropriate for CAC‑A?

choices.text: Heavy PPE: face shield, hearing protection, leathers

rationales.B: CAC‑A is loud and ejects hot metal; robust PPE is required.

stem: What coating type characterizes E7018 electrodes?

rationales.B: E7018 is a basic (low‑hydrogen), often iron‑powder type electrode.

stem: In the designation E7018, what does the '70' indicate?

rationales.C: The first two digits give the minimum tensile strength in ksi.

stem: What does the '1' in E7018 indicate?

rationales.C: The position digit '1' means the electrode is usable in all positions.

stem: Which polarity is commonly used with E6010?

rationales.B: Cellulosic E6010 typically runs on DCEP for deep penetration.

stem: Which technique is typical for open‑root welding with E6010?

choices.text: Fast weave to wash the toes

rationales.B: Whipping controls the keyhole and allows root fusion without excessive burn‑through.

stem: Why should E7018 electrodes be kept in a heated rod oven between uses?

choices.text: To prevent moisture pickup and hydrogen cracking

rationales.B: Dry storage limits hydrogen pickup that can cause cold cracking.

stem: What arc length is generally recommended for SMAW?

choices.text: Very long arc for better visibility
As short as practical, about the electrode diameter

rationales.B: Short arcs improve shielding and reduce spatter and undercut.

stem: Which condition commonly leads to undercut in SMAW?

choices.text: Excessive travel speed or a long arc
Low travel speed with short arc

rationales.A: High speed or long arc washes metal away from the toes, creating undercut.

stem: How can arc blow be reduced during SMAW?

choices.text: Lengthen the arc and increase current
Shorten the arc, move the work lead, or backstep
Switch to a larger electrode only

rationales.B: Short arcs and better return lead placement reduce magnetic arc blow.

stem: Why remove slag between passes with E7018?

choices.text: It is optional; slag burns out
To avoid slag inclusions and lack of fusion

rationales.B: Slag can become trapped and prevent bonding on subsequent beads.

stem: What is the main benefit of preheating thick or high‑strength steel before welding?

choices.text: It reduces cooling rate and hydrogen cracking risk
It eliminates the need for interpass cleaning

rationales.B: Preheat slows cooling and allows hydrogen to diffuse, lowering crack risk.

stem: What is a good practice when restarting a SMAW bead?

choices.text: Strike on the weld face and continue
Grind/feather the stop and restart slightly ahead to tie in
Do nothing; the slag will float out

rationales.B: Feathering and restarting ahead allow blending without defects.

stem: What are typical angles for a flat fillet weld with SMAW?

choices.text: 90° to both pieces with zero travel angle

rationales.A: A 45° work angle with a slight drag/push travel angle is common.

stem: What problem can damp E7018 electrodes cause?

rationales.B: Moisture in the coating adds hydrogen to the weld pool.

stem: Which electrode is best suited for deep‑penetration open‑root welding on rusty steel?

rationales.C: Cellulosic E6010 provides deep penetration and tolerance to light surface contamination.

stem: Which power source setting can E7018 typically run on?

rationales.B: E7018 is usually suitable for DCEP and often AC depending on brand/WPS.

stem: Which technique helps control heat when welding vertical‑up with E7018?

choices.text: Stringer beads (or limited weave) with pauses at the toes

rationales.B: Stringers with brief toe pauses help keep the puddle under control.

stem: What hazard is associated with welding galvanized steel?

choices.text: No special hazard compared to bare steel
Zinc fumes; remove coating locally and ensure ventilation

rationales.B: Zinc fumes are hazardous; remove coatings where possible and ventilate adequately.

stem: Which polarity is standard for GMAW and most gas‑shielded FCAW wires?

rationales.B: Solid and gas‑shielded flux‑cored wires typically use electrode positive (DCEP).

stem: In ER70S‑6, what does '70' indicate?

rationales.B: Like SMAW, the '70' refers to minimum tensile strength in ksi.

stem: Which shielding gas is commonly used for short‑circuit GMAW on carbon steel?

rationales.B: C25 (75/25) provides stable short‑circuit transfer with low spatter.

stem: To achieve spray transfer on carbon steel, what is generally required?

rationales.B: Spray transfer needs an argon‑dominant gas and sufficient current/voltage.

stem: Increasing voltage in CV GMAW (at fixed WFS) tends to:

choices.text: Narrow and stiffen the arc with deeper penetration
Widen the bead and increase wetting
Lower heat input and widen the bead

rationales.B: Higher voltage broadens the arc column, improving sidewall wetting.

stem: In short‑circuit GMAW, increasing inductance generally:

choices.text: Makes the arc harsher with more spatter
Softens the arc and reduces spatter

rationales.B: Greater inductance slows current rise, reducing explosive short clearing.

stem: What is the effect of excessive stickout/CTWD in GMAW/FCAW?

rationales.B: Long stickout increases resistive heating of the wire, reducing current at the arc.

stem: Compared with pulling, pushing the GMAW gun typically:

choices.text: Produces deeper penetration and narrow bead
Produces a wider, flatter bead with slightly less penetration

rationales.B: Push angles broaden the bead and slightly reduce penetration.

stem: What often causes 'worm tracks' in FCAW‑G deposits?

choices.text: Excessive voltage/heat or surface contamination causing gas channels

rationales.B: Gas bubbles under the slag can leave tracks when voltage/heat is high or surfaces are dirty.

stem: Which can cause porosity in GMAW?

choices.text: Drafts, improper gas flow, or surface contamination

rationales.A: Shielding disruption and contaminants allow gas pores to form.

stem: Which drive rolls are appropriate for FCAW‑S vs solid wire?

choices.text: V‑groove for FCAW‑S; knurled for solid
Knurled for FCAW‑S; V‑groove for solid

rationales.B: Knurled rolls grip tubular wire; V‑groove rolls suit solid steel wire.

stem: A common cause of 'birdnesting' in GMAW wire feeders is:

choices.text: Incorrect drive‑roll tension or liner size causing high drag

rationales.B: Poor feeding due to drag or excessive pressure can tangle the wire at the rolls.

stem: What typically causes 'burnback' (wire fusing to the contact tip)?

choices.text: Too short stickout or too slow wire feed relative to voltage

rationales.B: If burnoff exceeds feed, the arc retreats and fuses the tip.

stem: Why use crater‑fill or a back‑step at the end of a GMAW bead?

choices.text: To reduce crater cracking and underfill

rationales.B: Filling the crater avoids shrinkage cracks and underfill at the stop.

stem: Which transfer mode provides a continuous stream of metal droplets at high current?

rationales.C: Spray transfer delivers fine droplets axially across the arc.

stem: Metal‑cored (MCAW) wires typically require:

rationales.B: MCAW wires are gas‑shielded and need the correct gas mix per spec.

stem: A limitation of short‑circuit GMAW on thick plate is:

choices.text: Potential lack of fusion in grooves and fillets
It cannot run out of position

rationales.C: Low energy per droplet risks lack of fusion on heavy sections.

stem: Most self‑shielded FCAW wires run on:

rationales.A: Popular self‑shielded classifications (e.g., E71T‑8) use DCEN.

stem: In a CV GMAW system, which control primarily changes welding current?

rationales.B: At constant voltage, increasing WFS raises current and deposition rate.

stem: Why keep the GMAW nozzle and contact tip clean?

choices.text: To maintain gas coverage and stable electrical contact

rationales.B: Spatter buildup disturbs shielding and electrical continuity.

stem: What is a typical effect of increasing travel speed (all else equal)?

rationales.B: Higher travel speed reduces heat input, narrowing the bead and penetration.

stem: Which polarity is standard for GTAW on carbon steel?

rationales.A: DCEN focuses heat into the work for deep penetration and protects the tungsten.

stem: Which current type is commonly used for GTAW on aluminum?

rationales.B: AC provides electrode‑positive cleaning action to remove aluminum oxide.

stem: What is the purpose of a gas lens on a GTAW torch?

choices.text: Create laminar gas flow and extend shielding coverage

rationales.B: A gas lens straightens flow, improving shielding on joints with more stickout.

stem: How should tungsten be ground for GTAW on steel?

choices.text: With a blunt chisel tip only

rationales.B: Longitudinal grinding directs electrons axially and minimizes arc wander.

stem: What prevents 'sugaring' (oxidation) on the backside of stainless GTAW joints?

rationales.B: Inert purge gas shields the backside until the metal cools below oxidation temps.

stem: Which gas is commonly used for GTAW shielding and back purging?

rationales.A: Argon is inert and widely used for GTAW and purging.

stem: Which filler classification is commonly used for GTAW on carbon steel?

rationales.A: ER70S‑2 is a deoxidized solid filler rod for GTAW on carbon steel.

stem: Increasing the electrode‑positive (EP) portion of AC balance in GTAW will:

choices.text: Increase oxide cleaning but heat the tungsten more
Reduce cleaning and cool the tungsten

rationales.A: More EP enhances cathodic cleaning while raising tungsten temperature.

stem: What can excessive GTAW shielding gas flow cause?

choices.text: Turbulence that draws in air and contamination

rationales.B: Too much flow creates turbulence and aspiration of air into the shield.

stem: Which GTAW start method avoids tungsten contamination without scraping?

rationales.B: HF or lift‑arc initiates the arc without rubbing the tungsten.

stem: On aluminum GTAW, what provides oxide cleaning action?

rationales.B: The EP half‑cycle breaks the aluminum oxide film during AC welding.

stem: Why choose a larger‑diameter tungsten for higher currents?

choices.text: To handle higher heat without melting the tip
To avoid the need for filler

rationales.B: Bigger electrodes carry more current without overheating.

stem: Which positions are typical for submerged arc welding (SAW)?

rationales.B: The granular flux and high deposition rate suit flat/horizontal welding.

stem: How should SAW flux be handled to avoid porosity?

choices.text: Keep dry; bake per manufacturer if moisture‑contaminated
Mix with oil to bind dust

rationales.B: Moisture in flux introduces hydrogen and causes porosity; keep flux dry.

stem: Why might AC be used for high‑current SAW?

choices.text: To reduce arc blow and allow higher currents
Because DC cannot make quality welds
To eliminate the need for flux

rationales.A: Alternating current reduces magnetic arc blow and supports very high currents.

stem: What does SAW flux primarily provide?

choices.text: Shielding and slag formation around the weld pool

rationales.B: Granular flux supplies shielding, slag, and sometimes alloying elements.
